text.name: sys_description
text.text: The VIC-20 is an 8-bit personal computer designed by Commodore with 5 kb of RAM (including 3.5 kb for BASIC applications) and a central unit based on a MOS 6502 processor. It resembled its successors the C64 and the C16 . The VIC-20 appeared in June 1980, 2 years and 9 months after the release of Commodore's first personal computer, the PET. It was designed to better compete with the new Apple II as well as the Tandy TRS-80 and it sold a million copies. Due to its low memory and low-resolution display, it was used for educational or recreational purposes.
